title: Border states (Eastern Europe)
text:
Border states, or European buffer states, were the European nations that won their independence from the <a href="Russian%20Empire">Russian Empire</a> after the <a href="Russian%20Revolution">Bolshevik Revolution of 1917</a>, the <a href="Treaty%20of%20Brest-Litovsk">Treaty of Brest-Litovsk</a> and ultimately the defeat of the <a href="German%20Empire">German Empire</a> and <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a> in <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. During the <a href="interwar%20period">interwar period</a>, the nations of <a href="Western%20Europe">Western Europe</a> implemented a border states policy, which aimed at uniting them in protection against the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> and <a href="communist">communist</a> expansionism. The border states were interchangeably <a href="Finland">Finland</a>, <a href="Estonia">Estonia</a>, <a href="Latvia">Latvia</a>, <a href="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, <a href="Romania">Romania</a> and, until their annexation into the Soviet Union, short-lived <a href="Belarusian%20People%27s%20Republic">Belarus</a> and <a href="Ukrainian%20People%27s%20Republic">Ukraine</a>.
The policy tended to see the border states as a "<a href="Cordon%20sanitaire%20%28international%20relations%29">cordon sanitaire</a>", or <a href="buffer%20states">buffer states</a>, separating Western Europe from the newly formed Soviet Union. The policy was very successful. At the time, Soviet foreign policy was driven by the <a href="Trotskyist">Trotskyist</a> idea of <a href="permanent%20revolution">permanent revolution</a>, the end goal of which was to spread <a href="communism">communism</a> worldwide through perpetual warfare. However, the Soviet advance to the west was halted by <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, which managed to defeat the <a href="Red%20Army">Red Army</a> during the <a href="Polish%E2%80%93Soviet%20War">Polish–Soviet War</a>. After the war, Polish leader <a href="J%C3%B3zef%20Pi%C5%82sudski">Józef Piłsudski</a> made attempts to unify the border states under a federation called <a href="Intermarium">Intermarium</a>, but disputes and different allegiances between and within the group of states prevented such a thing from happening, leaving them more susceptible to possible incursions by their more powerful neighbors. The matter was further complicated by the rise of the expansionist <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> to the west. In 1939, Germany and the Soviet Union signed the <a href="Molotov%E2%80%93Ribbentrop%20Pact">Molotov–Ribbentrop Pact</a>, which included a secret clause that sanctioned the partitioning of several border states between the two regimes in the event of war. Only nine days after the pact was signed, Nazi Germany invaded Poland, and the Soviets followed suit shortly after, beginning <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> in <a href="Europe">Europe</a>. After the end of the war, all border states except for Finland were transferred to Soviet occupation as a result of the <a href="Western%20betrayal">Western betrayal</a> although Finland had already ceded some of its territory to the Soviet Union following the <a href="Winter%20War">Winter War</a>.
